prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for refusing to pay rent after I move out?
I’m almost 20 years old, and have been presented with the opportunity to move out of my moms house. I’d be moving in with my boyfriend and a few of our mutual friends, rent is $300 per person, including utilities (a steal around where I live.) One of the main reasons I want to move out is because since my parents split a couple years ago my mom has been treating me like a live-in babysitter for my younger brother. She has a fwb that she sees multiple times a week, where I only see my boyfriend once mayyyybe twice a week if I’m lucky. So I’ve informed my mom that I’ll be moving out soon and she was LIVID, solely for the fact that SHE won’t be getting $300 a month from me in rent. She said she can’t believe I would do something like this to her, and she cant afford to pay someone to watch my brother 3-4 nights a week. I told her that’s not my problem, but I will still give her $50 a month for my dogs food, and pay for when she needs to be groomed, because after all she is still my dog (I, unfortunately, can’t take her with me as pets aren’t allowed, unless it’s like a fish or something.) She demanded more money to “help pay other bills” and I told her that I was sorry but I have bills of my own to pay. She called me an ungrateful brat and is currently trying to prevent me from taking my stuff (which I bought) from the house, so I might have to call the cops to do a civil standby while i collect my things. 

So AITA for refusing to pay my moms bills after I move out? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the person is in the wrong here. So the user is almost 20 and wants to move out to live with their boyfriend and friends. The rent is $300 per person, which includes utilities, and the user mentions it's a good deal. The main reason they want to move out is because their mom has been using them as a babysitter for their younger brother since the parents split up. The mom is upset because she won't get the $300 rent anymore and can't afford to pay someone else to watch the brother. The user refuses to pay more than $50 a month for the dog's expenses, and the mom is now trying to block them from taking their stuff.

First, the user is moving out, which is their right. They're an adult almost 20, so they have the right to live independently. The mom is treating them as a live-in babysitter, which isn't fair. The user isn't legally obligated to pay rent to their parent once they move out. The mom's anger seems to stem from financial loss rather than genuine concern for the user. The user is offering $50 for the dog, which is reasonable since they still have a responsibility to the pet. The mom's refusal to let them take their belongings is a red flag; she can't legally prevent them from taking their own property. The user might need to involve authorities to retrieve their stuff, which the user is considering. 

The key points here are the user's right to move out, the mom's unreasonable demands for continued financial support, and the legal right to personal property. The user isn't in the wrong for refusing to pay rent after moving out. The mom's behavior is more problematic here. So the answer should be B (No).
